title: Sublime horror with a historical backdrop
review:
I must admit when I first saw this pop up on my Netflix choices as 'new' and saw that it had been released five years ago, I immediately became sceptical.With so many offerings in the vein of the Ring (2002), Saw (2004) AHS (American Horror Story) with the additional in vogue mashing of as many genres as possible, it's perfectly acceptable to be cynical before viewing any new horror films, wih many of todays most respected directors losing credibility in attempting to produce sophisticated, overly intricate, unnecessarily gory...well lets just say there are a lot of formulaic traps one can fall into with this genre, and fans now demanding more realism, more accuracy, continuity and authenticity and more than ever before.This film is set in the New England era of the mid 17th Century, with a small family being banished from their community for the so-called transgressions of their father who is accused of inappropriately preaching the gospels.The family (comprised of Mother and matriarch Katherine (Kate Dickie) Father William ( Ralph Ineson) eldest daughter and now hollywood celebrity (Anya Taylor-Joy in her first credited role) as Thomasin, along with younger brother Caleb (Harvey Scrimshaw) and the two youngest apart from the infant Mercy and Jonas (Ellie Grainger, Lucas Dawson).The family quickly settle on the edge of an ominous wood working hard to grow crops to survive.
Early on Thomasine is playing peek-a-boo with the samll infant boy, who mysteriously vanishes into thin air - and this is when things begin to fall apart.Without spoiling the plot, I was most impressed by the clever and subtle use of the films score to build a palpable, almost visceral sense of dread coming from the dark and uninviting woods.There is also an equally palpable feeling of claustraphobia in addition to dread, and despite the family's dedication to prayer and the maxims of the church, things just keep getting worse.What is a relief is the time spent on skillfully building suspense - not though cheap jump scares or other familiar and tired tropes, but through the interactions of the characters and their deteriorating health in response to the traumas visited upon them.Anja Taylor-Joy seems to have mastered the art of the extreme close-up, and one can tell that she is a skilled actress.This film is truly eerie, haunting and suspenseful, in a way that is almost exhausting emotionally, keeping the viewer engaged - as the plot moves forward the characters true motivations are difficult to discern.I especially appreciate historical accuracy in every aspect of a period piece such as this, and despite some minor mistakes reportedly with speech accuracy, Eggers does a wonderful job in his directorial debut.I wouldn't jump to say that this is high brow, overly layered or too allegorical, as some films aim to be - this film succeeds by relying not on exclusively visual triggers but by building upon auditory(musical, instrumental and vocal), emotional (the interplay between characters and their obvious trepidation) elements as well as anticipatory suspense which heightens the tension.I was immediately reminded of the screenplay I studied in high school - 'the Crucible', a loose and questionable account of the Salem witch trials.According to the films trivia much of the material was gathered from various primary sources, personal and official accounts which must also be applauded.A great example that a horror film need not be full of monsters, ghosts and demons dripping with gore, black and white notions of 'good v evil', and other oversimplified narratives of black and white morality and/or notions of the spiritual.

title: Doesn't Have Enough
review: Lets start with the positive.The atmosphere, the realistic village/home setting, the visuals and the audio are all absolutely outstanding. They really are, you can see the amount of effort the crew have gone to to make an authentic world for their film.The negative.The actual movie. God it's so boring. The basics of the story is fine and had the concepts of something interesting to explore (and does somewhat) but a lack of real drama and punch rob the movie of the factors that could have made this a great movie.

title: Good acting and imagery, very bad script.
review: I will be brief and to the point. Brilliant acting, amazing photography and atmosphere. Good camera work and directing. Extremely bad scenario, supernatural, horror is forced. I can write a lot about why the script is lame but I wish to keep this short, therefore in a few words, the script is weak philosophically, spiritually and psychologically. Again, very very forced supernatural horror.

title: A really great debut
review:
This film encompasses what it was like during the 1600s when religion was the main force that ruled over humans. Instead of uniting them, religion, more often than not, did exactly the opposite - that is the product of humanity's lack of truly understanding what religion is about and how to live in agreeance with its nature and God. Seven members of the family each represent one of the seven deadly sins, and it's fitting that they all end up accordingly to them. This film shows that believing in God and praying each night is not what religion is about - it's about being honest with yourself and others around you, and working your way to build strong relationships, both with yourself and others, which each character in this film failed to do - instead, they kept it inside and ended up severing the bonds between each other, all in their own unique way. Overall, this was an incredible debut from Robert Eggers, who continued to deliver with "The Lighthouse", and I can't wait to see what he does next.
8/10

title: I guess it's for grownups...
review:
Having seen many reviews where people didn't understand the film and its plot, my only assumption would be "I guess it's for grownups".
Having said that, however, I think it could definitely be shown and analyzed in high schools (not American, they wouldn't get it either) or even colleges for the technical aspects.Acting was on spot, cinematography gave us oil paintings that could have been hanging on museum walls. I found no plot-holes, that is, I understood the point of the bloody movie. And it fulfilled the wasteful need for a genre in 'horror', but in the way Brando described it in that other great one.Much work was put into the language of the time, the robes, the housing, the lifestyle and, more importantly, the way of thinking of the time and the place.I won't give it a 10/10 cause it's a theme we've seen far too many times already (it didn't teach me anything new) but it definitely is the best movie I've seen about that time and place and deserving of your sitting on a couch and unnerving yourself as it unfolds...

title: The Finale is the Best
review: The Finale is the best as a lovely ass can be seen.

title: Awful, waste of time
review: Bad plot, pointless dialogues, no interest at all.

title: Many distractions to fully enjoy
review: The movie is ok, but watching on TV, I had to keep switching the sound up when they were whispering and talking and sound right down when the overload dramatic music kept coming on... it was most irritating when there was not actually anything happening!! The main actor's voice (William) was slightly irritating and has such a distinctive voice, all I could think about was him doing voice overs for MANY history and UFO documentary's, so his voice was so off putting. The accents were also not at all consistent. However, the story was interesting, despite all the distractions.

title: Not your typical horror movie
review: I liked the fact that they used information from the period to construct the movie (otherwise I would have deducted a few stars).Unfortunately, I wish the script writers would have made the family more likeable:The twins were extremely annoying. I get it that small children can act obnoxiously. I get it that they communicated with the goat, so their actions were supposedly influenced by the creature. However, the twins were unbearable. Especially the boy. (If you can, watch the "making of" documentary to see how frustrating it was to get the boy to eat the bread. I would have found a different (much better) child actor after the sixth take).The Father was OK (given his Puritan roots), but the part about covering up the sale of his wife's heirloom made me dislike him. Also, why was he dismissed from the church at the beginning? At some point, I'll rewatch the first part of the movie with the captions turned on. Maybe it will make sense. He also seemed pretty useless as the head of the household.The Mother was annoying in nearly every scene. I understand that she's was mourning the loss of the baby and she wanted to go back to England, blah, blah, blah. She was a constant nag.The older son was depicted as a perv as he lusted after his older sister. OK. I understand that they're in the middle of nowhere and the kid is starting to notice girls, but come on. The skeeze factor made me dislike the son.The older daughter was OK. (I like her in most of her other movies). However, the script seemed to fall flat for her. Did her parents intend to sell her as a "maid" to a richer family or did they just want one less mouth to feed?Overall, I didn't really care what happened to any character. This could have been a very good movie if the script (and some of the acting) was better. This is not a horrible movie, but turn on the closed captions from the very start if you want to make sense of any of it.

title: Very captivating
review: I love the way this movies depicts the hardships the settlers had to conquer. It shows human suffering that I've read about that wasn't thought in school. It's a great thriller horror film that captured my attention. It was a simple story that was easy to follow, yet intriguing and kept me in tuned. Great movie.

title: I didn't care for the movie
review: Maybe it just wasn't my cup of tea?!! I see a lot of good reviews and that's what made me watch the movie but it was crazy to me. Then i couldn't understand what they were saying half of the time they're accents in the movie were very thick. I tried to cut on the CC but it didn't work so i was struggling to understand what they were saying the whole time. It was slow as well and wasn't really scary to me. Anyway. Check it out for yourself

title: A masterpiece that isn't for everyone
review: The Witch is an amazing atmospheric horror film, I'm reluctant to call it a horror as it's mostly a drama but there's always a sense of unease so I think it does slot into the horror category overall.The plot is not mainstream Hollywood at all, it's quite slow moving which may put people of if they're expecting quick action, scares and gore, it's best described as a slow burn. It involves themes of religion, isolation and, to a lesser degree, lack of finances.The acting was phenomenal, Anya Taylor-Joy was brilliant as the naïve but determined daughter and the hugely underrated actor Ralph Ineson was convincing as the stoic and hardworking William (the Father). Also notable is Kate Dickie as the mother and Harvey Scrimshaw as Thomasin's little brother Caleb.Cinematography is another strong point, the colour schemes are used extremely sparingly and skilfully, not quite being black and white but not dashed with so much colour as to lose the film's tone. Every shot is intelligent just like the director's other film The Lighthouse.10/10: A subtle masterpiece, thought provoking and brilliant. It will be very interesting to see what other films Robert Eggers directs.

title: This movie is too much for some people
review: People who didn't like this movie, only like films like saw, anabelle,insidious those films that have jumps scares and are east to watch, they thing is boring because the don't like character development, this film has great performances and pace, don't listen to the kids that say it is boring..

title: ''Thou shall not understand without subtitles''
review: I already knew a fair bit going into this movie but that definitely did not taint the experience. That said, title joke aside, subtitles..must need unless you're fluent in 17th century poetic english. Nothing to do with bad audio balance or anything.This is one of those movies that really transports you to such a different time in the world, even though it involves fantasy and fairy tales that are easy to digest and make fun of now. A couple hundred years ago it doesn't seem too far fetched especially with how tightly bound people were with religion. So you do really have to believe in that and put yourself in their shoes for this film to work. If you are christian, and a strong one at a that, I could imagine this movie having a more profound impact.The directing is top notch, from the very first shot of the jury, it's engrossing. The location is not diverse at all, but still they manage to find different angles and every shot feels different. Even though you are in the same house/area it's always show in a different way. The pacing is done well, though for a traditional ''horror'' movie I'd say it falls below the bar of what you'd ''expect''. There much more focus on the setting, the world, the characters, and religion. Yes there are a few moments of horror but it's sparse.The music is great. Really draws you in but also there's a lot of silence used in this movie which I can always appreciate.The acting is top notch. The male lead is undeniably captivating with his voice and way of speaking. But the young female performs just as good. If anything the small cast in this movie is just fantasti.The story. I'm a bit iffy on this. As much as I enjoyed the movie it felt somewhat lackluster in its ending. The moment after the mother is killed by Thomasin the movie quite quickly jumps into the ending and wraps it up very fast. Leaving you kind of deserted after the entire family drama. Also the whereabouts of the two little kids are also left unknown which seemed somewhat sloppy. I guess you could presume they were offered in the final scene and with their blood or whatever gave the witches power again. Because we also saw this at the start of the movie although I thought it was only limited to newborns to be sacrificed... Now a movie doesn't need to answer everything, but such a detailed and tight woven family in a very contained story.. I think it missed out.But all in all, I'd recommend this movie, it's not a style of film you come across a lot and it's worth a watch just for that, besides the fantastic directing, acting..etc8/10

title: Boring - Confusing - Annoying - Frustrating - Stupid - WAAAASTE OF TIME!!!!!
review: After reading the reviews here and hearing about the surprising success of this film, I was eager to watch it. I love plots involving history pieces as well as the possible paranormal. But as I started watching this movie, I found myself praying that there was just a slow build. Unfortunately, I found myself hoping for that up until the very end. The characters were annoying at best. The various elements and ideas introduced to move the plot along seemed to be only minimally explored. The two worst characters in my opinion, were the twins who, from the beginning, gave off an air that they could be evil. Yet when it is confirmed that they had been talking to the devil via a farm animal, the directors/writers still somehow maintained their characters as innocent children. The sporadic intense sequences seemed more tragic than spooky. And the ending was completely insane. A girl watches her whole family get murdered and is scared half to death then instantly decides that she wants to join a coven of naked floating women? Really? I was extremely disappointed in this film and even more in the misleading reviews on this site. I even double checked to make sure that I had watched the same film as those reviewing. So now I am just wondering if I can have the 1 and 1/2 hours of my life back...?

title: Eggers is a research scholar
review: I have seen his other films, some how i left Witch unseen for some reason, lately i have come to know that the director is a brilliant student of cinema.We can see discipline in his work, and mostly the stories he choses are the explanations or historical notes of the tales and fantasies.For example if we take "Witch". We have seen in other movies and in stories how witches looks and the story goes to a direction on the plans and destination of those witches, but here and in other films of Egger, He defines the reason how and why one could be a witch. Its a steady and strong strategy for using historics in films,Hes nailing it, just imagine hes giving background stories for the tales that hes been heard before, when he makes new in the future, how vigorously dark it would be..!

title: Huge disappointment
review: Main gripe - I had to put on subtitles to understand the thick, heavy accents. Knowing they were speaking English pulled me out of a suspension of disbelief. This was supposed to be disturbing psychological horror, which I love, but grew bored about 45 minutes in (about when I decided to put on subtitles). What a missed opportunity.

title: Different Kind of Horror movie
review:
A family discarded from the society, lives near the woods. And the bad things starts to happen. The Witch is not a regular supernatural horror movie. It is a different kind of horror movie. It doesn't give you random jump-scares from ghosts appearing in the scenes. But it psychologically impacts the viewers with the drama and story-telling. The 1630s England era has been shown beautifully. English language is little different in this movie as it took place in 1630s. Anya Taylor-Joy delivers impressive performance.
'The Witch' has good storyline, fresh concept and great direction. A must watch movie for the whole new horror experience.

title: Unnerving
review: I watched this movie because it was recommended to be "historically accurate" in the sense of their beliefs of the time, way of life etc.As someone who studied witches in my undergrad, it was interesting to watch. One critique is that historically those branded as witches were typically elderly women and/or widows. Powerful women, those very rare women, who inherited money from their husbands, were branded as witches. Killing them off was a way to maintain the status quo and steal their money (double win for them.) Also elderly women on the fringes of society were targeted because they were easy targets (few connections to anyone etc.)It is true that they thought witches were the devils minions and such utter nonsense. A very serious film based upon a very absurd belief.

title: great acting, atmosphere, psychology
review: True dark horror, relief from do many stupid slashers. It is intelligent, very well played, with good script. Sooo underrated

title: Give Me That Old Time Religion!
review: This is one of the most disturbing films I've ever seen. It takes place in the time of the Salem Witch Trials. A Calvinist minister, his wife, and five children are forced out of the small town in which they live. They have few practical skills and are at the mercy of the wilderness. Thomasin, the beautiful daughter maintains her sanity through most of the film as the others fall apart. But there is something truly dark at work. Excellent film but not for most viewers.

title: The Witch: A Psychological Paranoia
review: The Witch is a movie based on a family living in New England in the 1630s. At the beginning we see the family leaving a community over some dispute and they begin a new life all by themselves out in the woods. Soon after, the eldest child of the family Thomasin (played by Anya Taylor-Joy) can be seen playing with the new born child in the family out in an open field, close to the forest. And all of a sudden the new born baby disappears in front of her and thus rolls out the the very beginning of the destruction of the family. Because of such incident Thomasin is hated by her mother, and slowly we see incidents keep happening to the family which put suspicions on her. Although this a horror movie, but there are barely any scary scene. Unlike most of the horror movies there are no jump scares, no disfigured appearances. Instead it slowly builds up the plot of the movie and plays an interesting turn of events at the end. There are not much to talk about the the characters - the only important character is, of course, Thomasin. One other thing I liked so much about the movie is the setting, really astonishing. The Witch mesmerizes the audience by not letting them bore for a moment with sustained scenes of psychological paranoia.

title: 1 star reviewers should go and watch jump scares
review: People reviewing this as 1 and 2 stars are the ones who likes just stupid jump scare plotless stuff. This is really good film in every aspect.

title: Forced to become a witch
review:
After they left the plantation in the New England, they faced difficulties and the mother thought they were cursed as her youngest son disappeared and Caleb died and was damn*d. Caleb got lost in the woods with his sister and found the house the witch and met the witch the beautiful witch with the red hood and kissed by her which made him dam*ed. The father wasn't the master of the family. He can't hunt, he can't grow crops all he can do is chop wood as his daughter said to him. The other 2 kids believed their older sister is a witch. They even pretended not to be able to recite their prayers to make their parents believe that she's a witch. They stopped pretending when their father said he'd cut their heads off like Abraham did to his son. They spoke to the black goat. The black goat made them do it. The black goat and the hate in the wood.
I liked how she breastfed the raven while the white goat fed the witch in the shed with the kids with them. The black goat was the devil indeed and killed the father. And the mother kept thinking it was all her innocent daughter who did all of this. She had to kill her mother. She killed her while hugging her. And then the black goat spoke to her too. It pledged him a good life and the whole world to see. She joined the other witches around the fire and the black goat with them. They suspended in the air along with her. They made her a witch. They did it.

title: Not perfect, but dark and twisted.
review: For anyone saying this acting is "horrible", that simply isn't true. For anyone saying the script is bad, read more books. For anyone saying the plot doesn't make any sense, read The Crucible.The acting was phenomenal, the story was dark, the suspense was high. Anyone rating this movie a 1 quite literally doesn't understand the basics of a movie.Watch this movie, form your own opinion.

title: Not a movie for mainstream horror fans, slow burning, great acting, 1600s speak
review:
The type of horror this movie exhibits isn't the standard formula used in every film that comes out of suspense and jumscare, suspense in jumpscare. This movie instead prefers to slowly build and hold the tension as you watch this family fall apart. There is only really one or two jumpscares that I cant think of.
The story is somewhat lackluster and is instead more of a backdrop to provide an experience on.
The acting is fantastic the whole movie, especially impressing from the younger members in the cast, I don't know how some people seem to think it was so bad.
They speak like English immigrants from the 1600s which some people seem to really struggle with understanding but REALLY impacts the whole movie to immerse you.

title: Brilliantly shot.
review: This was the result of a director who not only painstakingly researched every aspect of colonial life in the 1630s, but who also executed his ideas with striking confidence. The aspects of the film (lighting, sound, dialog, pacing, composition) created an atmosphere so real I was no longer sitting on my couch watching, but rather living this inherited puritan nightmare.The movie's controlling idea is simple: The prevailing human desire to seek reassurance from a higher power can easily be twisted by ignorance, superstition, psychological insecurities and a horrendous misinterpretation of religion into a culture of self-flogging that nurtures guilt and fear until they become invincible beasts, then lets them lose on the mind to devour it whole. The result of this scary process is a flock of pariahs, known by the fancy, superstitious name of "witches" who live on the peripheries of society, devoid of any means of compassion, stripped of all sanity and civility, living in a world of morbid fantasies and diseased hallucinations in which they are left defenseless to their auto-cannibalistic minds that devour their sanity.The performances were also pitch perfect and very believable for the characters the actors played and, although this might prove hard to get by for some, they speak in period-authentic language/accents. Ultimately, the film is rather ambiguous as to whether or not the events occur in the manner you see them, but that's the beauty of it: like religion itself, THE WITCH is open to interpretation. And as such, it establishes itself (in my opinion) as one of the best horror films of the last 10 years.The Witch to me, is a brilliantly shot (natural lighting and using a different aspect ratio to get the sense of isolation), well acted and fascinatingly told. It is a simple story that leaves a big impact, if you are looking for an eerie, haunting film that will make you think.

title: for a horror movie it's 4/10
review:
It's very difficult movie to rate.
I wanted to give it 5/10 but I couldn't
here is why:great cinematography
great sound
great acting
great music
great depiction of the 17th century atmosphere especially the (religion,language) aspect
however, the story is simply just not as good.

title: A Wonderful Movie
review: A remarkable story.A typical Hollywood gore film ? Not all.A real horror story of a family that encounters an evil spirit.If you are looking for blood and guts and not much else, skip this movie as it will be over your head.

title: Seminal film in the history of the horror genre
review:
Having seen this film several times since its initial release in the theater, the feelings evoked here continue to resonate with me and so many fans of the horror genre. The Witch, in my opinion, is an achievement that has set the pace on several fronts:1. Horror that creates a sense of slow-burn unease, spiked by occasional moments of shock. This is a shift from the previously-omnipresent jump scare nature of this genre.
2. Horror that is historically-based, well researched, and thus is even "educational" viewing.
3. Horror that is actor-centric, while still clearly being atmospheric.
4. Perhaps the greatest achievement of his master-work, The Witch, was the ability to create and develop characters from centuries ago with dilemmas which resonate today.Kudos to Robert Eggers on his freshman effort, capturing the attention of many actors who now strive to work with this humble auteur of the art of film-making. Because of his recent work, and that of other young directors, I believe the future of horror is in good hands.

title: Weird Movie
review: I expected much more from this movie honestly , many things didnt really add up or make sense , and at some point it was just meaningless screams and all that stuff. The Plot wasnt really terrible but i mean the movie is supposed to have a witch in it and we see her like one time . In general , this movie isnt really that scary and the ending is kind dumb and i dunno if this movie was really worth watching at all. Recommended for anyone having nothing better to watch ,mediocre movie.

title: Everything I want from a psychological horror
review: Beautifully shot, strong performances, great editing, satisfying ending. If you're on the fence, just watch it; It's only an hour and a half and is sure to scare you at the very least.

title: Masterfully crafted, wholly original, profoundly moving and utterly terrifying
review: This is truly the greatest horror film of the 21st century. It is a period piece that is extraordinarily authentic, yet the attention to detail only adds to the dark atmosphere rather than distracting. The story feels like an eclectic blend of the dark strange atmosphere of "The Shining" and the drama of "The Crucible". Robert Eggers displays a powerhouse of technical filmmaking precision and masterful writing. The actors are incredible and the music is unforgettable. The story is biblical, horrifying, and devastating. This film is not for everyone; some may find the dialogue boring, but the attentive viewer will find it only adds to the hypnotic atmosphere. If you appreciate deep characters, story, and cinema as an art, you will love this film. I remember being so shaken by the ending that I couldn't breathe, and this will forever be one of my favorite horror films. 10/10

title: A masterpiece by all means
review: The plot , the setting, the acting, the cinematography, the direction, the horror ... this is probably one of the most underrated movies of all times , a masterpiece and a horror classic by all means

title: Excellent. Tense. Not a horror
review: Stunning acting. Constant mood of threat. Period detail spot on.People going on and on about it not having enough horror are way off bat. This is about religious fanaticism. Blind faith.The only annoying part was the mumbled dialogue throughout making it impossible to understand.Thought provoking. Disturbing.

title: A Piece of crap.
review: I don't understand the attraction to this movie. I feel that it was a total waste of time. Maybe religious people like it so that they can pretend that there is a devil.

title: If you like the usual horror blood and guts trope, this movie isn't for you
review: This movie is absolutely amazing. The acting is great, the story is captivating. I normally don't write reviews but I had to for this one. All the hate comes from the fact this is a smart psychological horror. It doesn't have the cheap jump scares, lots of blood and action like most horror genre have. This is more if a folk tale told over the centuries by a Puritan point of view on the supernatural had come to life. I absolutely love horror movies and if Freddy Kruger or Jason is your only idea of horror, this movie isn't for you. But if you like a truly interesting story telling over cheap blood and gore, I highly recommend watching this film.

title: A different genre
review: Slowly builds up, with just the right atmosphere, towards an unsettling finale.Successful characterization, giving the feel of the age the story is in. Makes you immersed in the story.This is in the same avenue as Hereditary and Midsommar. May not be some people's cup of tea, which is totally understandable.A good work, worth a watch.

title: Well, one version of the actual witch is ... hot; the rest of film ...
review: This film is perhaps unlike any other film I have seen. Yes, there is horror, but it is not the type of horror that might cause your girlfriend to cuddle closer. It's creepy; VERY creepy.The acting is superb; I actually tuned in to see another film with Anya Taylor-Joy after watching "The New Mutants", but alas, she is only about 20yrs old or so for this film --- younger than I prefer. But she IS a very lovely young woman.This film might have scored higher for me if I could have understood more than about 1/3 of the dialog -- much of it, I"m sure, may be Period-Accurate; but to me, unintelligible. Hence my lowish rating.Again this film is quite creepy. Set yourself up for a level of creepy that you may not have seen before; but you may enjoy the film as I did.

title: Not for Everyone
review: "The Witch" is the directorial debut from Robert Eggers and is about a series of unfortunate events plaguing a family after they choose to depart from their village. "The Witch" stars Anya Taylor-Joy, Ralph Ineson and Kate Dickie. Now this was a film I was quite looking forward to as I am a huge horror movie geek and I had heard nothing but positive things about the film. Now I must say this was probably my favourite film I have seen so far this year, however it is not for everyone. Just everything about this film I thought was incredible, just on a technical stand point the cinematography in this film was a sight to see and adds so much to this enthralling story which you can so easily get lost in. This movie was very interesting for the fact that it takes place in the 1630's and includes a mix of shakespearian and modern english dialogue which could have went one of two ways, either it'll sound really forced coming from the actors or they'll sound completely genuine and the audience will totally buy into the schtick. Luckily this is a case of all the actors being completely stellar and strong enough to deliver these performances that were shown in this movie, I did not think there was one flat performance and even when one of the actors seemed to falter he really won me back with a deeply disturbing scene where he just lets loose. Now like I was saying this movie will not be for everybody, many people will go into this expecting a horror film similar to many of the mainstream horror movies released nowadays and they will be thoroughly disappointed as "The Witch" is not one of those films flushed out with a bunch of jumpscares. This is a methodical film that takes its time to build itself up and some people may not be used to that and I am here to to tell you today that even though this film advertises seeing the witch itself, you actually see the witch less in this movie than you do the babadook in "The Babadook", this is not meant as a spoiler but more of a warning. So "The Witch" was a deeply suspenseful film that affected me on many levels, I couldn't take my eyes off the screen through the whole runtime, the score for this film was another profound aspect, I absolutely loved the way the it built up. Though I had slight problems with the film such as the strong english accents being hard to understand sometimes and colour palette being too grey at times, they didn't detract away from the film, for that reason "The Witch" receives a 10/10.

title: Please don't watch.
review: It was slow and boring and lead up to nothing. And they speak old English. Just dreadful.

title: Ok.
review: This movie seems to feature highly in the modern horror movie recommendations online.Don't know what all the fuss is about and I'm not quite sure what to make of it.I'm not sure this is what I would call horror or particularly good for that matter.Just ok really.

title: Not good. Disappointed. Not horror. Not worth seeing.
review: Disappointed. Not horror. Not worth seeing. Borring.

title: Who wrote the good reviews? Are they okay?
review: So. Yeah. This was the stupidest movie ever. I don't care what category they add it under, it sucked. A more exciting movie would be watching someone smash their head into a wall for two hours. Literally though; who? Who are you people who gave this a good review? And what exactly are you on? 😂 42 y/o female - NJ USA.

title: Damn the movie felt wrong
review: Its not exactly horror, but it will definitely make you terrified, A must watch if you want to see something different.

title: Witch history
review: Seeing that this movie takes into account for a few stories of witches is good. I love this time period of early American colonial period. The imagery of the black goat and the young children love for role play as witches makes you wonder if they had communication with the devil. I loved Anya and Ralph's characters ( and Ralph's voice). Thomasin is being accused as being the witch, which we find who is later. The Witch overall is a great movie.

title: Lame
review: This movie TOTALLY SUCKED!! Do not waste your time, seriously

title: Its heart lies in the right place...
review: As someone who avoids watching horror movies in general, I didn't really know what to expect other than it being a slow-burner. The movie establishes clearly in its first quarter that the horror is not merely psychological, but tries to make you believe in its universe of witchcraft.Till its climax, I was expecting some sort of logical explanation to the events being depicted but it hit me in the final moments the kind of horror which the makers wanted to depict.I especially loved the performances by the child actors and get the polarising reviews it might get because it is certainly not a movie for everyone.

title: Not as scary as I thought it'd be.
review:
Not to say scary is better, but this movie left a shorter impression on me than Robert Eggers' other film, The Lighthouse, which is one of my favourite films of all time.
The acting, dialogue, and music were all great in this film. However, at least upon my first viewing, I don't see many themes or overarching morals/ideas as I do in The Lighthouse.
Something interesting I noticed is that it shares a lot of parallels with Midsommar, but with many aspects flipped. Instead of being indoctrinated, they're exiled. Instead of it being eternal day during summer, most of the horror takes place at night in winter. Instead of the evil coming from within the group, it's an external threat. Instead of beautiful visuals, it's drab and unsaturated.
The VVitch also reminded me a lot of Hereditary, mostly in story arch and the ending. However, I know The VVitch came out before both of these films, so perhaps they took inspiration from The VVitch.
This is still a solid movie though, and was unnerving in several parts, but seeing The Lighthouse first may have skewed my expectations a bit too high.
If you like this movie, I couldn't recommend Midsommar or Hereditary enough.

title: Slow, bleak, disturbing. One to avoid.
review: I wanted to write this to provide a counter to some of the rave reviews I saw here. In summary, the film is slow, disturbing and frankly irritating. I would avoid unless you've got a taste for slow, bleak, artsy films.In my opinion, the plot was near enough non-existent. Basically it tells a story of a deeply pious family being torn apart by outside forces. Sounds alright, but in execution it amounts to actors reciting long drama school type scripts (in difficult to understand old English) interspersed with long bleak shots of not much and the odd quite disturbing scene.At times the overbearing sound track (lots of screechy violin!), crying, wailing and carping on was actually just plain annoying.I don't think this would be to the taste if your average film lover. I'd only recommend it if you like a film that makes you uncomfortable.

title: Made for a particular audience...
review: This movie will be loved by cinephiles but less so by the average moviegoer. This New-England folktale has a slow, moody build with a poor payoff. They do a good job of staying true to the puritan history, language, costumes, and settings. The acting is decent from the older cast, especially the eldest daughter and father but the youngest cast (acting and script) almost takes away from the cleverness of the film. There are no real scares except for the intense build and creepiness of it all but, the ending was a huge letdown for me and ruined the whole film. There are some artistic and creative moments for this film but all-in-all I wouldn't recommend this movie to the average horror/thriller audience, more for a film buff/movie critic In My Humble Opinion. 10/2020

title: 92 minutes wasted
review: I can't believe this won awards. I can't believe this won awards.

title: very haunting and very scary
review: This movie is very scary in a psychological aspect and is horrific

title: Waste of time
review: Terrible movie. Wish I never wasted my time.. no storyline, no plot, just s***. How on earth can this movie have a rating like this, we thought it would be worthwhile because of it.. we were so wrong.

title: does a whole lot with just a little
review: This is a prime example of solid filmmaking. transporting us seamlessly back in time to the colonial era, when even a small mistake can end in life-canceling tragedy, the Witch takes the basic fears of being human and manifests them in the form of a devil Goat. The witch plays on the ubiquitous fear of the unknown. How well do we know our family, ourselves? The effects in the movie are minimal and make that much more of an impact when we see them. The ending sequence alone is worth the 10 star rating. This is a must-see for all horror, suspense, historical and general film fans!

title: Terrifying
review: One of the best horror movies I've ever seen. So well-made. I love this movie so much that it has become an annual Halloween tradition. It's nerve-wracking and intense.

title: Long, boring
review: How this got any good ratings is beyond me. The acting is fine. The movie isn't. This could boil down to an episode of some horror anthology, and STILL bore its audience. Definitely NOT a movie that I would recommend. It just made me glad I didn't live in those times!

title: Worth the drag
review: Watching with subtitles definitely helps. The movie is pretty long and draggy, but the payoff is worth the wait.

title: Disappointing
review: Half way through I realized it was slowly building... to nothing. The ending was beyond disappointing, most obvious and meaningless. And what's up with audio being so bad? Could not hear anything being said, yet the noises were so loud, made it even harder to enjoy.All that while I love witches, the colonies, indie horror and even Eggers' second movie the lighthouse.

title: Awfully boring
review: NOT A HORROR MOVIE. IT WAS JUST ABOUT A FAMILY IN THE 1600S LIVING OUT IN THE MIDDLE OF NOWHERE AND GOING MAD RELIGIOUSLY. oh yeah and a there's a goat dabbling in the black arts. STUPID!!

title: A slow burn that gets stoked
review: I give credit where credit is do, the film does create a intense and creepy atmosphere. The actors do a good job. But the movie is slow and boring. And the whole time your waiting for the unveiling of something brilliant. It never happens. It's a huge disappointment...

title: Boring!
review: I was hoping for something better than what this was. Bored beyond belief, extremely slow story telling, tries too hard to be suspenseful. I didn't give up on it and now wish I wouldn't have bothered watching.

title: Surprisingly good; completely unexpected.
review: I was ready to hate this movie, as I was expecting the standard, vicious assault on Christianity by hard-Left Hollywood that has sadly become the norm . I gave it a try anyway, and I'm so glad that I did. Although I needed to turn on the subtitles to grasp much of the dialogue, this didn't detract from my enjoyment of the film at all. It's a beautifully-crafted film & very well-acted. Excellent casting and it features a magnificent attention to detail. It's a film that I'll definitely be wanting to see again, which is VERY rare these days. Not for children or those with short attention spans, but patient, thoughtful adults who have at least a minimal understanding of history should enjoy this rare gem.

title: What?
review: Can you understand ANYTHING they are saying? Low voices, too quiet or just an accent that is way too much. Sorry, too much for me.

title: Will keep you guessing till the end....
review: I've read many reviews here and have decided the people who give it 1 star don't understand the history of Puritanism and the Salem witch trials and satanism. Whether you'll enjoy this depends on whether you know this history and what your expectations are from "horror" movies.If you don't know the history, you'll likely find the "possession/symbolism" of animals and the constant focus of everyday life as related to "God",ie; ...is what I'm or others doing consistent with God's will and word and if it's not...it's the work of Satan, as ridiculous and overstated/acted. For those who know the history, the Witch is a very emotional slide into what can happen to the average human when every action and word is weighed as of God or Satan. The horror comes slowly and is wrapped up in the question of is there really a witch/Satan running the show here or is it just insanity or are they one in the same. Even in the final scene I questioned whether everything was really happening or was it just in Thomasin's mind. Puritans truly believed in Satan's power and interference in daily life. Things such as crop failure, illness, even moles on a body were taken as signs of the devil so it is easy to understand how a young girl who just witnessed the death of her family but wanted to be "free" would in shock, bring all her beliefs into one final delusion....or did she. I love walking in the woods but after this movie, I expect to be a bit jittery and probably won't do it alone!

title: Very scary at the end
review: This movie takes a while to get going, but is very scary in the ending. Would recommend to those who enjoy the story over getting jump scared all the time.

title: Amazing
review:
This was disgusting, horrifying and ghastly as it should be.
Loved it👌

title: Is boring a new film genre?
review: This movie was just plain boring. This is the kind of movie people will say is magnificent, is a tour de force of film making, blah blah blah. The same kind of people who tell you movies like "The Babadook" and "Hereditary" are also excellent films. The kind of movie that your fem. lit. teacher will tell you to watch as she/zhe/zhir/whatever goes on and on about systems of oppression and how witches were the first real feminists. Unfortunately, even science and engineering majors have to take garbage courses like fem. lit.It made a good attempt at trying to be authentic in terms of setting, and it has a gritty dirty feel. No comforts at all.It's not scary. It doesn't make you think about religion and supernatural forces anymore than watching "Ancient Aliens". And at least with "Ancient Aliens", the sound editing is better, this movie has moments when the actors are hardly understandable.

title: Easily one of the worst films I've ever seen
review: I don't know what some reviewers have been smoking, but this film doesn't deserve anything above a 1. Nothing happens at all. I genuinely would rather sit on the toilet with severe diarrhoea then watch this again. Please believe me. Don't waste your time. 1/10

title: Slow-burning adult horror story sculpted around actual historical supernatural beliefs
review: Horror isn't my favorite genre, but I like to dip into it periodically. I'm coming off of losing 2 hours of my life to a rather ordinary yet over-rated zombie flick (specifically, "Train to Busan"), so there's a good chance that I'm tacking an extra star on presently because this exceptionally well-crafted, high-quality production is catching me on the rebound."The Witch" isn't a conventional modern horror film and will leave those yearning for jump-scares, screams, and over-flowing guts wanting much more probably. It also builds slowly and feels longer than its runtime, although this is one of the rare cases when that isn't a bad thing. Still, most younger audience members will probably be reaching for their phones soon. In addition, the "Olde English" the characters use takes some getting used to and almost requires subtitles at times, or at least it did for me. On the other hand, like Shakespeare, you really don't have to get every word or phrase to easily follow the story. As is mentioned at the end, the plot was crafted around actual medieval witchcraft folklore and trials. Therefore, if you're familiar with that history, as the story progresses, you vaguely feel that you know where its all going. Personally, this film felt like it was ripped straight from my own personal cultural DNA, being that I'm one of those particularly loathsome creatures, in other words, an aging, well-educated, western, white male.This movie really got under my skin as it went along and effectively erased the prior cinematic misfire, for which I'm very grateful. Zombies may have run their course with me. "The Witch" is time very well spent, even if you don't carry my particular cultural baggage. It's probably too slow and inadequately bloody for many or most of today's horror aficionados, but it works great as adult horror entertainment which sneaks in legitimate education about "olde-tyme", western, witchcraft beliefs. A win-win, as I see it and maybe for you too.

title: Henceforth. Thou shall live Delicious.
review:
Horrorfilm of 2016... You bet your sweet derriere. Writer-director Robert Eggers' viciously delicious slowburner represents all that's good about low-budget terror.Shunning his religious community, patriarch William and his family take to the wilderness to try and start anew.
Misfortune however, seems to plagued the venture at every turn, not only does the crop keep failing but their infant son disappears, seemingly gobbled up by the ominous woods looming large over the family' habitat.
As conditions worsen, the family unit begins to self-destruct, all under the watchful eye of the households malevolent billy goat Black Phillip.Making rumbles since its debut at Sundance 2015, The Witch has been long awaited by yours truly. Did it live up to expectations? Did it ever!
The Witch is an amazingly taut and focused horror movie.
Debutant Eggers has an iron tight grip on proceedings and shows no qualms about how he's going to go about telling his story. The script, cinematography, acting and score, all of the highest order, effortlessly amalgamates into one hell of an unsettling and disturbing horror experience.
Best of all, he manages all of this without pandering to the lowest common denominator, instead trusting the audience to find their own way in getting his point across.Last but certainly not least, special props must go to the amazing creation that is Black Phillip, a 210-pound billy goat named Charlie, who apparently ran roughshod over the cast and crew during production. Well I'm here tell you that their trails and pain was worth it as Phillip (short as his appearance may be) will no doubt join the annals of horror lore as one of the greatest animal performers ever, so effective is his performance in the film.
As a matter of fact, He might as well rise onto his hind legs - now rather the later - and violently bang his majestic horns at the endless night sky, bellowing out in celebration as he and his fellows have just crafted one of the greatest horror offerings of the 21th century.Baaaaaaaaaa!!! Indeed.

title: One of the most effective horrors of all time
review: Why did I make the decision to watch this movie on a dark, stormy night(that's a cliche I'm aware)? This movie is a slow burn horror movie with some disturbing visual and eerie feeling throughout. I am not going to list actors and how brilliant they were because every actor shone in this film even the child actors. The production of this films is one of my favorites as it was almost all done practically. The dialogue and it's use of Old English is amazing and proves Eggers is a master of his craft despite it being his first role directing. The use of sound in this film is my new favorite for a horror movie with its use of chants and silence. The light from candle and the darkness really add to the eeriness. I can not praise Eggers enough for this as it was his first movie he ever directed and makes me want to see his new movie The Lighthouse even more. The film is probably the scariest horror movie I have ever seen(it might have been where and when I watched it but I do not believe this is true). I highly recommend this film for a constant suspense and scares. It's well worth checking out on Netflix.Also I love that the film does not rely on cheap jump scares which ruin films upon rewatch. I feel if I watched the film again then it would have the same eeriness.

title: Not your typical "horror" film...this is MUCH BETTER
review: I am not a fan of horror films, but I do recommend watching this film. This is not a typical horror film; I describe it as a psychological thriller about witch-craft and devil worshiping beliefs of the 1600's. There is a constant state of wonder about who is the "witch" or evil one? Watch it because it is a well-crafted story.The cinematography really brings it to life. The setting looks very authentic and the low lighting reminds you that you are watching a film before electricity. Watch it because the cinematography will take you back in time.The acting is superb! Many young actors and I cannot say enough about their performance. They all did a great job with the Colonial language and mannerisms. The young man who played "Caleb" (Harvey Scrimshaw) deserves to be in more films, as he was outstanding. The young lady playing "Mercy" (Ellie Grainger) was scary for such a young actor and Anya Taylor-Joy was both innocent and frightening in her role as Thomasin. Watch it because the acting is excellent.

title: Nothing special
review:
I watched this film after watching same director's other movie "The Lighthouse". This film was nothing but a slow family drama questioning their belief in God and descending into madness.
Talking of acting, it was not upto the mark but you spend the movie waiting for a big finale which does not happen. The story was simple, nothing special. Overall, would say that it will be better for you to watch same director's other work "The Lighthouse" which was much better than this.

title: Wth...
review:
I honestly don't know what I just watched...
I was looking for a good scary movie to watch on a date, and this movie was not helpful. I don't think there was a single scary scene, maybe one... but the entire movie is just slow.
I read the other reviews and I see that most people like it, but I just don't understand how, it's slow and not scary. The acting and cinematography was good, but this is not what I would consider a good movie. Very forgettable...

title: Hard to watch
review: The movie seems like it would be decent. Sorry is ok. Acting is fair.The huge problem is the poor job done in post production. The music and sound effects are way too loud and overbearing. I found myself constantly turning up the volume just to hear the muffled dialogue and then the very next minute there was screeching music that was near deafening.It doesn't really suck one in when they have to sit there with the remote constantly adjusting the volume. it's pretty annoying in ruined the whole movie experience.

title: "Wouldst thou like to see the world?"
review: Wow, this movie is really good.I watched this movie last night and went in with no knowledge or expectations and went to bed unable to stop thinking about it... The user rating is completely misleading, and I can definitely see this movie being mentioned among the classics maybe 20 years from now.This film shows an accurate portrait of "if a devil chose to haunt a peasant family, this is how it would've happened"--There were no crazy make-ups, top notch CGI effects, the goat transforming into Lucifer with cheesy noises. They kept it as natural as they could. Even when the goat spoke to Thomasin, they kept the camera on the girl, because it was the audience's choice whether he spoke telepathically, or with his goat mouth and then him appearing behind the girl in complete darkness, showing nothing but only enough parts so the audience knew he was no longer an animal. (Side Note that was by far my favorite scene in the movie).Now, I can kinda understand why some didn't really enjoy this movie. I get that some watch a movie for entertainment and to pass the time, but some of us look at a movie like they would a painting. Looking for subtle messages everywhere. So I can sympathize a bit with why some people found the movie boring, because the pace was definitely slow. However, I personally found the slow pace of the story to be perfectly appropriate. I really liked the slow buildup to the end.I'm pretty sure keeping the audience's adrenaline high wasn't their main goal. There were scenes that you had to pay attention to if you wanted to know what the hell was going on. For example: Black Phillip knew the exact buttons to push to seduce everyone. The mother wanted to see her children, and he had them appear to her, making her read a book that was likely demonic. Caleb was going through puberty, and he was full of lust. So, a beautiful woman appeared that Caleb could not resist. The father, on the other hand, was impenetrable. He wanted nothing but forgiveness from God, so Black Phillip straight out killed him.Despite its slow pace (which i thoroughly enjoyed), the movie made its point very clear. And the point was how attractive the devil's side could be in some cases--actually, not in some cases but in any case. Even the audience is forced to sympathize with the girl at the end, for "choosing the dark side." Because God did nothing in return of the entire family's prayers. Her whole family was murdered by Lucifer, and even if she didn't go to meet Black Phillip, stayed in the house and did her prayers, what would change?I guess the thing I love most about this movie is it truly feels like real folklore people would have passed down the generations. "Don't be like that family, don't leave the warm embrace of the tribe or you'll end up being corrupted by the devil" and so forth...I'd say "The Witch" is more of a "film" than a movie...it has loads of artistic value. Like any quality "film" this isn't made to appeal to the masses. It is what it is and it does it extremely well. This is a film i'd definitely recommend to others who enjoy well made period pieces. (8.5/10)

title: "Wouldst thou like to see the world?"
review: I watched this movie last night and went in with literally no knowledge or expectations and went to bed unable to stop thinking about it...The IMDb user rating is completely misleading, and I can definitely see this movie being mentioned among the classics maybe 20 years from now.What makes this movie stand out from others for me is that it shows an accurate portrait of "if a devil chose to haunt a peasant family, this is how it would've happened"--There were no crazy make-ups, top notch CGI effects, the goat transforming into Lucifer with cheesy noises.They kept it as natural as they could. Even when the goat spoke to Thomasin, they kept the camera on the girl, because it was the audience's choice whether he spoke telepathically, or with his goat mouth.(By far my favorite scene in the movie) And then him appearing behind the girl in complete darkness, showing nothing but only enough parts so the audience knew he was no longer an animal.Now, I can kinda understand why some didn't really enjoy this movie.
